Award.AwardTitle: Understanding and Performing High-Resolution Surface-Wave Attenuation Measurements with USArray
Award.AbstractNarration:
"Understanding and Performing High-Resolution Surface-Wave Attenuation Measurements with USArray"

This project focuses on making use of seismic wave amplitudes to achieve high-resolution images of the Earth's crust and upper mantle. Velocity imaging using the travel times of surface waves has been extremely successful, but interpretations of these velocity images are non-unique. The amplitude analysis performed here constrains not only velocity structure, but also density and attenuation structure. This extra knowledge helps solve the non-uniqueness problem, allowing better constraints on key features of the North American continent's deformation history, evolution, and geochemical and tectonic structure. In particular, the high-resolution attenuation measurements are potentially sensitive to features such as magma and partial melt, water and other volatiles, as well as fault structures through the differing dependencies of these features on intrinsic attenuation as compared with seismic velocities.

This work provides higher resolution images compared to previous attenuation and density imaging due to the confluence of vastly improved station coverage by USArray with new data processing techniques. On one hand, developments in theoretical and empirical techniques allow for utilization of ambient noise attenuation tomography, even when the noise sources are non-uniformly distributed. These ambient noise methods promise to allow for improved spatial resolution compared to earthquake-based studies due partly to the increased frequency band over which measurements are successful. On the other hand, developments in array-based phase-front tracking and amplitude mapping make it possible to use the dense station coverage of USArray to account for focusing and defocusing effects and to reduce the influence of source uncertainty. The convergence of this theoretical, numerical and empirical work allows for accurate measurements of surface-wave amplitudes, both for ambient noise and earthquakes, and allows for the density and attenuation imaging considered here.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Traditionally, most seismological studies have focused on measuring the travel times from earthquakes to seismic stations to image Earth structure. However, it is known that the velocity information obtained in this fashion cannot be uniquely related to the compositional or thermal structure of the Earth. Moreover, this travel time information only provides indirect constraints on how earthquake ground motions are amplified by local geologic structure near the site of interest. To address both of these issues, we have directly measured surface-wave amplitudes across the North American continent. In order to accurately make these amplitude measurements, we have designed new methods that make use of the dense station coverage of seismometers provided by USArray, which account for the focusing of waves and complexities in the sources of waves. To better understand how our measurements are related to the damaging waves caused by earthquakes, we have also analyzed how the type of wave measured results in differing amounts of amplification. For example, we have found that waves that propagate vertically through a low-velocity basin are amplified differently than surface waves that propagate horizontally through the same low-velocity basin. These differences in amplification imply that earthquake ground motion estimates made with one wave type do not accurately predict ground motions due to other types of waves. Our framework provides a way to account for these differences, and can potentially be incorporated into ground motion estimates, which in turn could result in more accurate earthquake building codes and thus lowering the hazards from earthquakes.

To test the methodology of measuring amplitudes and correcting for complexity, we first applied our new method to a dense 5000-sensor industrial survey deployed in the city of Long Beach. Results were favorable, and showed that we could constrain the local amplification of waves by fault-zone structure as well as large-scale attenuation of waves in the Long Beach area.

With the USArray data, we performed two different sets of analyses. The first analysis used a modified approach of measuring amplitude ratios rather than the raw amplitudes to make similar types of measurements, and had the advantage of being insensitive to certain instrumental errors. These results demonstrated high sensitivity to shallow crustal structure across the western United States, including both constraints on velocity structure and density structure. Particularly interesting shallow (1-3 km depth) low density anomalies are imaged in central Oregon, southeastern Utah and southwestern Wyoming. The second set of analyses directly measured amplitude differences as described above, and resulted in anomalies compared with predictions from velocity models, as well as constraining wave attenuation quantitatively. These high-resolution measurements of structure of the North American continent have demonstrated the utility of dense seismic array measurements, and point to specific elements of the history of the North American continent that still need to be better understood dynamically.
